Award.AwardTitle: Low-Cost, Manufacturable Approaches for Wafer-Level Generation of Nanoscale Device Arrays

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to investigate the use of a novel inexpensive printing approach for patterning wafer-level, parallel assemblies of nanoscale electronic materials for biological and chemical sensing from DNA templates. To address features smaller than 20 nm yet still maintain low manufacturing costs, the proposed research will combine a novel soft lithography stamping technique with patterned silicon surfaces to build ordered, spatially defined arrays of DNA and peptide-DNA based scaffolds on flat polydimethylsiloxane. These patterns can then be easily transferred to any receiving flat substrate, such as thermal oxide, metals, or polymers. Limiting the number of nanostructured oxide or silicon substrates needed in the fabrication process will dramatically lower manufacturing costs, while biomolecular scaffolds, such as DNA templates, can address features below 20 nm. The four main research objectives of the proposal are to 1) integrate low-cost, high-throughput inking and stamping methods to generate large area patterned arrays of DNA scaffolds, 2) engineer larger, well-controlled assemblies of DNA scaffolds, 3) incorporate specific molecular recognition motifs to bind nanoscale electronic materials in high yields and with minimal defects, and 4) fabricate fabricating multiplexed parallel, addressable biosensing electrical arrays.

An inexpensive, high throughput method to generate wafer-level arrays of nanoelectronic devices and sensors via benign chemistry and engineering would have an enormous impact on both the electronics and healthcare industries. Despite the wealth of nanoscale materials available, the current limitations of photolithography have prevented the realization of their potential in these applications. The proposed education and research plan will also draw and encourage active participation from teachers and students to help young students learn more about nanoscience and its impact upon society and their everyday lives. In addition, various seminars and interactive demonstrations related to the proposed research will be integrated into existing and new curricula, and open laboratory sessions will be held during university open-house days and on-campus science festivals.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of the proposed research is to develop high-yielding, low temperature, inexpensive routes for universal substrate patterning of wafer-level, parallel assemblies of nanoscale electronic materials for biological and chemical sensing. One of the most challenging but potentially rewarding areas in nanoscience is the ability to direct the assembly of nanoscale materials onto functional architectures with high yields, minimal steps, and inexpensive procedures. Furthermore, in order to utilize these technologies in health and energy applications, it will be necessary to provide manufacturable routes to assemble nanoscale materials that require limited or no expensive semiconductor tooling. As a means to address features smaller than 20 nm yet still maintain low manufacturing costs, this research project investigated methods to combine biomolecule inking (stamping) with nanoimprint-generated surfaces to build ordered, spatially defined arrays of DNA and peptide-DNA based scaffolds on polymer substrates, such as polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS), that can then be easily transferred to any receiving flat substrate, such as thermal oxide, metals, or polymers. By requiring a single silicon master that can be used repeatedly enabled low manufacturing costs while still allowing addressability at the sub-20nm length scale.

The development of a low-cost, high throughput method to generate wafer-level arrays of nanoelectronic devices and sensors that also uses benign chemistry and engineering methods would have enormous impact on both electronics and health industries. Despite the wealth of nanoscale materials that may benefit electronic based applications, the current limitations of photolithography have prevented the realization of their potential. Patterning substrates with smaller feature sizes often also requires expensive lithographic tooling. Furthermore, since many applications, including wearable chemical and biological sensors, require flexible, lightweight, plastic based electronics, there have been many efforts to discover alternate, more universal routes for developing high throughput methods to self-assemble nanoscale devices, regardless of substrate. The research developed in this proposal addresses some of these challenges by developing low-cost, low-defect, high-throughput, environmentally-benign techniques.

In the past three years, significant accomplishments have been made toward the overall objectives of the program. First, we have developed a low cost and facile approach for generating DNA arrays on substrates with 20nm resolution. This was accomplished by engineering a novel subtraction printing method which requires the generation of a single patterned silicon master that can be reused multiple times. Because the entire process is done using soft printing techniques, DNA nanopatterns can be printed on both hard and flexible substrates and sequential printing techniques can be used to produce 2- and 3-d arrays of DNA on surfaces. In addition, we have engineered techniques to use the DNA arrays to control nanoparticle organization in both 2- and 3-dimensions on surfaces. In this work, metal nanoparticles could be organized into hexagonal or BCC arrays site specifically by confining the nanoparticles to printed DNA sites on a surface and using biomolecular associative interparticle interactions to generate thermodynamically stable arrays of gold nanocrystals with significant long-range order observed over 1-2 microns. By tailoring the DNA on the surface and the DNA on the nanoparticles, thin film assemblies ordered in both 2- and 3-D could be produced in 2 steps. Control over film thicknesses could also be achieved simply by changing the initial gold nanoparticle concentration adsorbed to the DNA arrays. After thermal annealing, close packed nanoparticle thin films that showed extremely smooth top surfaces were obtained. Sin...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The main objective of the proposed research is to develop high-yielding, low temperature, inexpensive routes for universal substrate patterning of wafer-level, parallel assemblies of nanoscale electronic materials for biological and chemical sensing. One of the most challenging but potentially rewarding areas in nanoscience is the ability to direct the assembly of nanoscale materials onto functional architectures with high yields, minimal steps, and inexpensive procedures. Furthermore, in order to utilize these technologies in health and energy applications, it will be necessary to provide manufacturable routes to assemble nanoscale materials that require limited or no expensive semiconductor tooling. As a means to address features smaller than 20 nm yet still maintain low manufacturing costs, this research project investigated methods to combine biomolecule inking (stamping) with nanoimprint-generated surfaces to build ordered, spatially defined arrays of DNA and peptide-DNA based scaffolds on polymer substrates, such as polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS), that can then be easily transferred to any receiving flat substrate, such as thermal oxide, metals, or polymers. By requiring a single silicon master that can be used repeatedly enabled low manufacturing costs while still allowing addressability at the sub-20nm length scale. The development of a low-cost, high throughput method to generate wafer-level arrays of nanoelectronic devices and sensors that also uses benign chemistry and engineering methods would have enormous impact on both electronics and health industries. Despite the wealth of nanoscale materials that may benefit electronic based applications, the current limitations of photolithography have prevented the realization of their potential. Patterning substrates with smaller feature sizes often also requires expensive lithographic tooling. Furthermore, since many applications, including wearable chemical and biological sensors, require flexible, lightweight, plastic based electronics, there have been many efforts to discover alternate, more universal routes for developing high throughput methods to self-assemble nanoscale devices, regardless of substrate. The research developed in this proposal addresses some of these challenges by developing low-cost, low-defect, high-throughput, environmentally-benign techniques. In the past three years, significant accomplishments have been made toward the overall objectives of the program. First, we have developed a low cost and facile approach for generating DNA arrays on substrates with 20nm resolution. This was accomplished by engineering a novel subtraction printing method which requires the generation of a single patterned silicon master that can be reused multiple times. Because the entire process is done using soft printing techniques, DNA nanopatterns can be printed on both hard and flexible substrates and sequential printing techniques can be used to produce 2- and 3-d arrays of DNA on surfaces. In addition, we have engineered techniques to use the DNA arrays to control nanoparticle organization in both 2- and 3-dimensions on surfaces. In this work, metal nanoparticles could be organized into hexagonal or BCC arrays site specifically by confining the nanoparticles to printed DNA sites on a surface and using biomolecular associative interparticle interactions to generate thermodynamically stable arrays of gold nanocrystals with significant long-range order observed over 1-2 microns. By tailoring the DNA on the surface and the DNA on the nanoparticles, thin film assemblies ordered in both 2- and 3-D could be produced in 2 steps. Control over film thicknesses could also be achieved simply by changing the initial gold nanoparticle concentration adsorbed to the DNA arrays. After thermal annealing, close packed nanoparticle thin films that showed extremely smooth top surfaces were obtained.
